instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.A2179: What is A2179? A2179 is a model number for a 13 inch size MacBook Air from years Early 2020 with EMC 3302, that may contain one of these boards depending on the year & configuration: 820-01958..
definitions.820-01958: What is 820-01958? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PP5V_G3S: What is PP5V_G3S? PP5V_G3S is a 5v power rail present when the system is in a G3S standby state.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2179</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> - <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01958</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - Heavy Coffee Damage - 20V 0.05A->0A->0.05A Fluctuating <SIGNAL>PP5V_G3S</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
Merry Xmas, Healthy and Prosperous New Year.


<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> ok
<SIGNAL>PP5V_G3S</SIGNAL> - 5V -> 0V -> 5V

T2 heats up and down.

Heavy corrosion around the Tpad/KBD board
Corrosion around: U31/3200, <CHIP>U3060</CHIP>, <CAPACITOR>C6406</CAPACITOR>/6415, <RESISTOR>R5410</RESISTOR> area, <CHIP>U9060</CHIP>, <TRANSISTOR>Q7660</TRANSISTOR>/80, <TRANSISTOR>Q7065</TRANSISTOR>, <TRANSISTOR>Q7401</TRANSISTOR>, <RESISTOR>R7430</RESISTOR>

There are no shorts anywhere. <CHIP>U7800</CHIP> Diode mode seems to match a functioning board

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2179</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> - <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01958</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - Heavy Coffee Damage - 20V 0.05A->0A->0.05A Fluctuating <SIGNAL>PP5V_G3S</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
Something else affected by corrosion.
Possibly accumulated crap underneath BGA chips.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2179</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> - <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01958</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - Heavy Coffee Damage - 20V 0.05A->0A->0.05A Fluctuating <SIGNAL>PP5V_G3S</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
I have reflowed the BGAs CD32s/<CHIP>U6400</CHIP>/<CHIP>U6860</CHIP> which had liquid around. Is there other way to localise why <SIGNAL>PP5V_G3S</SIGNAL> is fluctuating without a short?

Or do I need to keep pulling these BGAs out and resoldering them back?

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2179</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> - <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01958</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - Heavy Coffee Damage - 20V 0.05A->0A->0.05A Fluctuating <SIGNAL>PP5V_G3S</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
Do you note the pulse on 1V8/<SIGNAL>3V3_G3S</SIGNAL> too?

Try to force the board in DFU.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2179</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> - <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01958</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - Heavy Coffee Damage - 20V 0.05A->0A->0.05A Fluctuating <SIGNAL>PP5V_G3S</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
Tried DFU with no luck, both with a jumper on <SIGNAL>SOC_FORCE_DFU</SIGNAL> and a spare keyboard

1.8_G3S Pulsing
3.3_G3S not Pulsing

Resoldered most MOSFETs and ICs that had liquid around. Reflowed U28/2900 too
Reballed CD32's. They had quite a crap accumulated underneath.

The last reflow BGA left is T2 but didn't have much liquid around. Mainly between T2 and <CHIP>U9060</CHIP>

PPDCIN_G3S - 20V
<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> - 12.6-12.3V slightly pulsing

Seems all PMIC voltages are pulsing with the same beat as <SIGNAL>PP5V_G3S</SIGNAL>

[ATTACH type="full" width="282px" alt="20231224_102235.jpg"]61438[/ATTACH]

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2179</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> - <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01958</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - Heavy Coffee Damage - 20V 0.05A->0A->0.05A Fluctuating <SIGNAL>PP5V_G3S</SIGNAL>
threads.message: Any suggestions? This is a data recovery case, The Customer is desperate.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2179</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> - <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01958</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - Heavy Coffee Damage - 20V 0.05A->0A->0.05A Fluctuating <SIGNAL>PP5V_G3S</SIGNAL>
threads.message: Compare diode mode readings on (many-many) points with good board, or reference table...

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2179</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> - <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01958</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - Heavy Coffee Damage - 20V 0.05A->0A->0.05A Fluctuating <SIGNAL>PP5V_G3S</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
Went through majority of the test points mostly match, some doesn't but i dont have them marked as test points on the board view so cant confirm what they are for.
Looking around these corroded ones in <CAPACITOR>C6415</CAPACITOR>,<CAPACITOR>C6406</CAPACITOR> area. 
[ATTACH type="full" width="268px"]61448[/ATTACH]
I do not have any short to the <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> there and chip is not shorting. Only suspicious part seemed to be <SIGNAL>SPKRAMP_INT_L</SIGNAL> which still measures 0.46Vdc in diode mode at <RESISTOR>R6400</RESISTOR> test point, which aligns with a functioning board board. However, this trace leads to T2 and I am wondering if trace leads from the test point instead from the <RESISTOR>R4600</RESISTOR> to the T2. 
[ATTACH type="full" width="282px"]61449[/ATTACH]

Can you remind me what the _L was in the trace name? Would this line needs to be hold low for normal operation?

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2179</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> - <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01958</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - Heavy Coffee Damage - 20V 0.05A->0A->0.05A Fluctuating <SIGNAL>PP5V_G3S</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
The "_L" refers to an active low signal.
An interruption sent from speaker amp to T2 may not be desired.
However, I recommend to compare the signals with good board.
I think we already got mismatch with speaker amp reset from Apple.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2179</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> - <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01958</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - Heavy Coffee Damage - 20V 0.05A->0A->0.05A Fluctuating <SIGNAL>PP5V_G3S</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
Active low being low when it needs to communicate (being active) and should not stay low most of the time?

I get on both boards' same readings for these
<SIGNAL>SPKRAMP_INT_L</SIGNAL> - 0.46Vdc
<SIGNAL>SPKRAMP_RESET_L</SIGNAL> - 0.43Vdc

To compare the signals I will need a scope, I have a signal analyzer but I doubt it will be a fit.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2179</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> - <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01958</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - Heavy Coffee Damage - 20V 0.05A->0A->0.05A Fluctuating <SIGNAL>PP5V_G3S</SIGNAL>
threads.message: These ared DC signals, no need to use o-scope.
